notes:
1. Time Value of Money

The core principle of engineering economics is that money has a time value. A dollar today is worth more than a dollar a year from now, because a dollar today can be invested to earn interest. This relationship between interest, time, and money is the foundation of economic equivalence.

2. Equivalence

Equivalence is the concept that different sums of money at different points in time can be equal in economic value. For example, given a certain interest rate, a payment of $100 today might be equivalent to a payment of $110 in one year. Equivalence depends on the interest rate ($i$) and the time ($n$).

3. Interest and Interest Rate

  • Interest is the compensation paid for the use of borrowed money. It is the difference between an ending amount of money and a beginning amount of money.
  • Interest Rate is the ratio of the interest charged to the principal amount, over a certain time period (usually a year).

4. Simple vs. Compound Interest

  • Simple Interest: Interest is calculated only on the original principal amount. The total interest earned is $I = P \cdot n \cdot i$, where P is principal, n is number of periods, and i is interest rate per period. The future value is $F = P(1 + ni)$.
  • Compound Interest: Interest earned in each period is calculated on the original principal plus the accumulated interest from all previous periods. The future value is $F = P(1 + i)^n$. Unless stated otherwise, interest is always assumed to be compounded in engineering economy problems.

solvedExamples.question: What is the future worth of $1,000 invested for 5 years at a simple interest rate of 6% per year?
solvedExamples.explanation: For simple interest, the future worth is $F = P(1 + ni)$. $F = 1000(1 + 5 \cdot 0.06) = 1000(1 + 0.30) = 1000(1.30) = $1,300$.

solvedExamples.question: What is the future worth of $1,000 invested for 5 years at an interest rate of 6% per year, compounded annually?
solvedExamples.explanation: For compound interest, the future worth is $F = P(1 + i)^n$. $F = 1000(1 + 0.06)^5 = 1000(1.06)^5 = 1000(1.338225) \approx $1,338.23$.
